Description: Computation as statements that directly change a program state (datafields)
Main characteristics: Direct assignments, common data structure, global variable
Critics: Edsger W. Dijkstra, Michael A. Jackson

Description: A style of imperative programming with more logical program structure
Main characteristics: Structogram, indentation, either no, or limited use of, goto statements

Description: Derived from structured programming, based on the concept of modular programming or the procedure call
Main characteristics: Local variable, sequence, selection, iteration, and modularization

Description: Treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions avoiding state and mutable data
Main characteristics: Lambda calculus, compositionality, formula, recursion, referential transparency, no side effects
Examples: Erlang, Haskell, Lisp, Clojure, Scala, SML, F#, SequenceL, Python

Description: Program flow is determined mainly by events, such as mouse click or interrupts including timer
Main characteristics: Main loop, event handlers, asynchronous processes

Description: Treats datafields as objects manipulated through pre-defined methods only
Main characteristics: Objects, methods, message passing, information hiding, data abstraction, encapsulation, polymorphism, inheritance, serialization-marshalling
Examples: Common Lisp, C++, C#, Eiffel, Java, PHP, Python, Ruby, Scala

Description: Defines computation logic without defining its detailed control flow
Treats programs as a model of a finite state machine or any other formal automata
Main characteristics: State enumeration, control variable, state changes, isomorphism, state transition table
